title: Immune Responses to Seasonal TIV 2010-2011 Influenza Vaccination in Humans (see companion study SDY396,SDY564)

producedBy.name: Immune Responses to Seasonal TIV 2010-2011 Influenza Vaccination in Humans (see companion study SDY396,SDY564)

usesReagent.name: The 2011-2012 WHO Influenza ragent kit for identification of influenza isolates
TaqMan Universal PCR Master mix, no AmpErase UNG

values: Is participating in other vaccination studies at the University of Rochester Medical Center.
Able to understand and comply with planned study procedures.
Is pregnant or less than 4 weeks postpartum.

Has donated blood for transfusion purposes, or participated in another research study involving blood donation, within 56 days of enrollment, or has already donated 450 mL of blood total in this study within the last 56-days including study blood samples and blood donations for subsequent transfusion use.
Is using oral or parenteral steroids, high-dose inhaled steroids (>800 mcg/day of beclomethasone dipropionate or equivalent) or other immunosuppressive or cytotoxic drugs.

Has any condition that would, in the opinion of the site principal investigator place the volunteer at an unacceptable risk of injury or render the subject unable to meet the requirements of the protocol.
Is undergoing immunosuppression as a result of an underlying illness or treatment.
Provide informed consent prior to any study.

Has an active neoplastic disease or a history of any hematologic malignancy.  Exceptions to this exclusion criteria are: Subjects may have Basilar Cell Carcinoma, Squamous Cell Carcinoma, or their malignancy has not been active for at least 5 years.
Has a history of receiving immunoglobulin or other blood products within the 3 months prior to enrollment in this study.

creators.name: University of Rochester Center for Biodefense Immune Modeling II

values.value: Our Center proposes to develop and refine multi-compartment, multi-level and multi-type mathematical/computational models for immune responses to vaccinations and infections of biodefense pathogens such as influenza viruses which will be tested and validated via the data from murine experiments and human studies. Our utmost goal is to develop modeling approaches to explore whether the rich in vitro and in vivo data from appropriate animal experiments, in combining with limited data from human studies, can be used to better predict human immune responses to vaccination and infections using both traditional modeling methods and cutting-edge systems biology approaches coupled with high-throughput technologies.   https://www.fbo.gov/?s=opportunity&mode=form&id=5a22e454d60d8d3a8a6701faa058d2b7&tab=core&_cview=1

primaryPublications.authorsList: Li X(1), Miao H, Henn A, Topham DJ, Wu H, Zand MS, Mosmann TR.
primaryPublications.title: Ki-67 expression reveals strong, transient influenza specific CD4 T cell responses after adult vaccination.

primaryPublications.authorsList: Henn AD(1), Wu S, Qiu X, Ruda M, Stover M, Yang H, Liu Z, Welle SL, Holden-Wiltse J, Wu H, Zand MS.
primaryPublications.title: High-resolution temporal response patterns to influenza vaccine reveal a distinct human plasma cell gene signature.

availability: Available for download after registration with ImmPort

dimensions.description: Flow cytometry analysis of PBMCs pre and post influenza vaccination.
To study activation and maturation of human B cell subpopulations after Influenza vaccination to build and validate immune response model using flow cytometry.
To determine concentrations of Influenza specific IgA, IgM and IgG antibody subtypes in human after TIV and LAIV vaccination.
To assess influenza specific antibody secretion rate of activated B cell subsets following seasonal Influenza vaccination in human subjects
Transcriptome analysis of  seasonal Influenza vaccine activated, class switched human B cells revealing gene regulatory network
Transcriptome analysis of  PBMC revealing gene regulatory network in seasonal influenza vaccinated human subjects
To determine antibody response to vaccine virus and other viruses in seasonal influenza vaccinated human subjects.
To confirm and validate changes in mRNA expression of selected B cell differentiation genes

distributions.title: Immune Responses to Seasonal TIV 2010-2011 Influenza Vaccination in Humans (see companion study SDY396,SDY564)

acknowledges.name: University of Rochester Center for Biodefense Immune Modeling II

description: To use system biology approaches to compare differences in immune responses to vaccine
